Harriet Tubman was one of the greatest Americans who ever lived. She put her life on the line time and time again for the freedom of her fellow Americans. She exemplified bravery and honor and service. She stood for liberty and justice for all. #WomensHistoryMonth http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FNlbEBpWQAEw0M4.jpg

She continued to work, becoming an important voice in the effort to expand voting rights to America's women.

Congress eventually passed a bill to give her a small, reduced pension of $20 per month. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FNla_FCXMAYzIUN.jpg

Later in her life she lived in poverty. Her status as a Black woman made it nearly impossible to get the pension she had earned in the war. She faced other discrimination. A train conductor threw her from a train car, breaking her arm. She was scammed and robbed.

As the war progressed, she became a nurse and scout, then put the "General Tubman" title to the test, becoming the first woman to lead an armed assault during the Civil War and leading a mass evacuation of over 750 slaves, many of whom joined the war effort.

Meanwhile, she spoke, and organized. The abolitionist John Brown called her "General Tubman." When the Civil War began, she continued to fight for abolition, condemning Lincoln for his timidity. "God won't let master Lincoln beat the South till he does the right thing," she said.

They had to flee to Canada because pro-slavery politicians in the U.S. had passed the Fugitive Slave Act to allow slavehunters to come North and kidnap escaped Americans. ‚ÄúAfter that," said Tubman, "I wouldn‚Äôt trust Uncle Sam with my people no longer." https://www.history.com/topics/black-history/fugitive-slave-acts

Tubman was five feet tall but fierce as lightning. She carried a revolver, even once using it to threaten a man who gave into fear and wanted to turn back, endangering the whole group. Reportedly, she told him ‚Äúyou‚Äôll be free or die.‚Äù They made it to Canada together. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FNlahafWUBATh9j.jpg

She spoke of the experience of winning her own freedom: ‚ÄúWhen I found I had crossed that line, I looked at my hands to see if I was the same person. There was such a glory over everything; the sun came like gold through trees, and over the fields, and I felt like I was in Heaven‚Äù

Today, Tubman is famous for her work with the Underground Railroad. She once said, "I never ran my train off the track and I never lost a passenger.‚Äù

She undertook 13 missions in 11 years, rescuing around 70 enslaved Americans.

There was one of two things I had a right to ‚Äì liberty or death. If I could not have one, I would have the other."

Harriet Tubman died yesterday in 1913 after a lifetime of fighting for freedom and justice. #WomensHistoryMonth http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FNlaVANX0AIIUGn.jpg
